mosimage.caption: The India Meteorological Department has ruled out the possibility of a deficient monsoon

listicle_content.listicle: North-West India will receive 108 per cent rainfall of the Long Period Average while central India and southern peninsula will receive 113 per cent of LPA.
The North-Eastern Region is expected to get 94 per cent of rainfall which is \"below normal\".
Anything less than 90 per cent of the LPA is termed as a \"deficient\" monsoon and 90-96 per cent of the LPA is rated as \"below normal\".
Monsoon is considered \"normal\" if the LPA is between 96 and 104 per cent of the LPA.
\"Above normal\" monsoon is between 104-110% of the LPA and anything beyond 110 per cent is considered \"excess\".

Agriculture, which contributes 15 per cent to India\'s GDP and employs about 60 per cent of the country\'s population, is heavily dependent on the monsoon as only 40 per cent of the cultivable area is under irrigation.
Due to poor monsoon in 2015-16 crop year (July-June), 10 states have declared drought and the Centre has sanctioned about Rs 10,000 crore by way of relief to help the farmers.

story.storykicker: The India Meteorological Department on Thursday said 96 per cent chances are that the rainfall this year would be normal to excess.
story.storybody:
The India Meteorological Department has ruled out the possibility of a deficient monsoon. IMD on Thursday said 96 per cent chances are that the rainfall this year would be normal to excess.

On Tuesday, Agriculture Minister Radha Mohan Singh had said India will "definitely" see higher foodgrain output and overall growth in the agriculture sector in case the IMD prediction of a good monsoon "comes true".

{mosimage}

Here's What IMD Predicts:

{funfacts}
  1. North-West India will receive 108 per cent rainfall of the Long Period Average while central India and southern peninsula will receive 113 per cent of LPA.
  2. The North-Eastern Region is expected to get 94 per cent of rainfall which is "below normal".
  3. Anything less than 90 per cent of the LPA is termed as a "deficient" monsoon and 90-96 per cent of the LPA is rated as "below normal".
  4. Monsoon is considered "normal" if the LPA is between 96 and 104 per cent of the LPA.
  5. "Above normal" monsoon is between 104-110% of the LPA and anything beyond 110 per cent is considered "excess".
  6. Agriculture, which contributes 15 per cent to India's GDP and employs about 60 per cent of the country's population, is heavily dependent on the monsoon as only 40 per cent of the cultivable area is under irrigation.
  7. Due to poor monsoon in 2015-16 crop year (July-June), 10 states have declared drought and the Centre has sanctioned about Rs 10,000 crore by way of relief to help the farmers.
{funfacts}
story.magazinekicker: The India Meteorological Department on Thursday said 96 per cent chances are that the rainfall this year would be normal to excess.
story.shortheadline: Monsoon to be normal or excess this year, predicts IMD: Quick Facts
